*STATE POLICE IMPAIRED DRIVING REDUCTION EFFORT (S.P.I.D.R.E.) TEAM*
The following incident was captured on in-car and body camera
Defendant: Scott Edward Baier

TRAINING/CERTIFICATES:
* I am trained and certified in administering standardized field sobriety tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (March 2013 SFST NHTSA Manual).
* I am NHTSA certified Standardized Field Sobriety Testing Instructor as of February 2016.
* I am a Certified Breath Test Operator by the Toxicologist of the State of Maryland as of March 2016.
* I have successfully completed Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (ARIDE) training as of March 2016.
* I am a distinguished graduate from the University of Maryland's DUI Institute as of June 2015
* I am trained and certified to operate RADAR and LIDAR through the Maryland State Police as of May 2014.
* I am a Preliminary Breath Test Instructor as of May 2019.
* I am a RADAR and LIDAR Instructor as of October 2019.
* I have apprehended more than 1,000 impaired driver’s during my tenure with the Maryland State Police to date.

VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1)
On February 24, at approximately 2355 hours, I (Cpl. Wallace #6323) was on patrol in unmarked Maryland State Police vehicle DUI-1 on eastbound Bowleys Quarters Road towards Carroll Island, Baltimore County, Maryland. I observed a black Chevrolet Trailblazer approaching my location from the opposite direction. The Chevrolet swerved left over the solid double yellow line onto my side of the roadway as it approached, then swerved right onto the correct side of the roadway. I made a U-turn and caught up to the Chevrolet bearing Maryland registration “FP1268”. The Chevrolet swerved left, then right. Right onto fog line, then left. Left over solid double yellow line with both driver side tires. The Chevrolet was traveling above the posted 30 MPH speed limit. I activated the front antenna of my Golden Eagle II Radar (S/N: EG-02387), which is a directional radar, in the moving mode (same). I heard a Doppler tone indicative of the estimated speed and obtained a speeding reading of 44 MPH in a posted 30 MPH zone (my radar unit was checked before and after my shift and was functioning properly). I activated my emergency equipment and conducted a traffic stop on the Chevrolet.

The above referenced RADAR was calibrated before and after my shift and was functioning properly. I am a certified RADAR operator. Training certificates and calibration records will be made available upon request. This RADAR is specifically assigned to my vehicle.

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2)
I approached the Chevrolet on the driver side and made contact with the male operator of the vehicle, who was the only occupant in the vehicle. I explained the reason for the stop and requested his driver’s license and vehicle registration. He was identified by his Maryland driver’s license as Scott Edward Baier. While speaking with Baier, I detected a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and person. I deliberately observed his eyes to be bloodshot and glassy. He was unable to find his registration card. I asked him what year his vehicle was and he asked, “This car?”. His movements were slow. I returned to my patrol vehicle to notify the barrack who I was out with.

I returned to the Chevrolet and requested Baier to exit his vehicle and walk to the front. He complied and exited his vehicle. He staggered forward when exiting. While speaking with Baier outside the vehicle, I detected a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and person. When asked about alcohol consumption prior to driving, he stated that he had a couple beers at OPI. When asked how many he stated 10 Ultras (started at 6 o’clock, stopped when he left). He was swaying while standing still. I informed Baier that I wanted him to perform standardized field sobriety tests, to which he agreed to the tests.

PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3) 
My patrol vehicle’s forward emergency lights were deactivated during all three tests. He was wearing a gray zip up, blue shirt, jeans and black Sketchers (tied).

I asked Baier the following questions: 

Glasses or contacts – No
Head Injuries - No
Medication –Blood pressure
Problems with knees or ankles – No

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (6/6 clues observed) 
The Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test was explained and administered per the NHTSA SFST Manual.
- Equal pupil size and equal tracking, no resting nystagmus
  1. Lack of Smooth Pursuit – Present in both eyes
  2. Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation – Present in both eyes
  3. Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees – Present in both eyes 
  • How often do you drink? A couple time a week.
WALK AND TURN (1/8 clues observed - Did not complete the test) 
The test was properly explained and demonstrated per the NHTSA SFST Manual.
Baier stated that he understood the instructions and how the test was to be performed.
Instructional Stage: 
  1. Lost balance offline to the right 6 times and the left 1 time.
  • I live right here.
  • Stated he did not want to do the test.
  • Asked, “Can I tell you my brother in law in a State Trooper. Does that help?”
  • I live right behind this house.
  • He doesn’t help?
ONE LEG STAND (Did not complete) 

PBT #209455 with a result of .16 BrAC.

ARREST
Due to the number of observations, I concluded Baier was driving under the influence and unable to operate a vehicle safely. At approximately 0007 hours, I placed Baier under arrest for driving while under the influence of alcohol. He was placed in the front passenger seat per department policy and was transported to the Maryland State Police Golden Ring Barrack for processing.

Upon arrival at the barrack, I provided Baier with a copy of the DR-15 Advice of Rights. Baier listened to the DR-15 Advice of Rights from the MVA website. At 0038 hours, Baier agreed to take a breath test.

20 MINUTE OBSERVATION PERIOD:
I conducted the 20-minute observation period with Baier beginning at 0010 hours. A search revealed that he had nothing in his mouth. Baier was observed from that time until the time he submitted to the test and he did not put anything in his mouth. The test was conducted by Sgt. Twardowski of the Maryland State Police on a certified instrument. Baier had a result of .19 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath at 0049 hours.

INTOXIMETER RESULT: 
****.19 grams of alcohol****

Baier was polite and cooperative during the encounter. Baier was given all copies of pertinent paperwork and released.

All events occurred in Baltimore County, Maryland.

Case closed by arrest.
